reviewText:
First note, I would like to say that I played in the alpha of this game - which was not on steam. This means that the hours displayed here does not show my entire experience.

Type of game: 3rd person dungeon runner / dungeon master - Casual gamer appeal.
You have two different playstyles in this game. You either raid dungeons made by NPCs or players, for gold, that is  spent on upgrading your own hero or your own castle.
Alternatively you devote your time maximizing your own defenses against the raids from other players, seeking to steal your treassures.
The game somewhat requires you to explore both playstyles.

Graphics, Audio and controls:
The game looks nice, feels nice - and sounds nice. I'd probably give it a 10/10 on this.

Review: The first 7-8 levels are the most fun you will have in this game, but in turn it is challenging and enjoyable.
In the beginning levels you will see a wide range of dungeons, some which are challenging, some are easy - and some downright impossible. This started very fun and was utmost enjoyable, but soon turned to be a tedious grind.
The castles eventually turned into clones of eachother as certain trap builds were proven more effective than others, and that's when the game seized to be fun. After raiding the 10th castle in a row with the same trap setup (catapult block + mines), at which point i was getting somewhat used to dodging and breaking the traps by running on and off them, i no longer had fun. This is where I changed over to only working on my own defense, and tried very hard to make something fun but nothing remotely close to the trap build. I did and do still enjoy the defending part of this game, but as the prices for upgrades and similar went up, I found myself having to either wait a month or to grind NPC castles over and over 100 times to get an upgrade.
As a gamer with plenty of experiences grinding, I came to the conclusion that I did not feel the results were worth the effort, which is when I stopped playing this.

Conclusion:
Fun game to try and play for a while, but it gets incredibly tedious and grindy for what is supposed to be a casual game.

reviewText:
I found it hard to find a good description of what this game actually is. In short it is a mostly solo action-rpg with a castle building side. Gamplay is all about attacking other players' castles with one or your heros while getting cool stuff and designing your castle to be bigger and badder.

Your main interaction with other players is attacking their castles and visa versa. There's no co-op in that you cannot form a party and go raid castles together.

Its F2P and at the time of writing has an in-game currency. Though I've so far not really needed to drop real cash on this. A pity in a way, I would have bought this game if it was just on the normal pricing model.

Anyway, IMO the game is fun as hell. Castle building is fun, easy, and deep. Raiding others' castles is fast paced and people have some great designs that can be really tricky and awesome. Since the game makes you run your own castle, I've yet to run into anything that was impossible or glitchy or hacky.

I particularly like that you can rate and comment on any castle you raid. I like being able to give people feedback on their designs, especially the ones that really presented a challenge.

Update (2/5/2015): I'm level 20 now and, unfortunately, the have and have-not nature of this game is becoming apparent. There's people who've paid and those who haven't. You can tell cause one group has amazingly tough castles and the others don't.

While you can technically get everything you need for elite creatures, boss creatures, and amazing traps... its slow enough that you will have to grind for a long time to have a properly equipped castle.

If you care about having a castle that can actually kill invaders, protect your gold, and earn you leaderboard points, then you need to pay. Its a really long grind to make a castle that's good enough without spending real money. Its really hard to kill players in this game and you've gotta craft (which is the chokepoint) a lot of stuff to get there.

Is it still worth playing? I'd say so, but if you care about leaderboard rankings and competitions, then be prepared to shell out at least for the infinity pack.

They made the game now pay2win. Also my review is no longer accurate because they overhauled pretty much the entire game. It's a totally different game now, and it only got worse. I uninstalled it and will never play it again.


Beta review:
I played this game for many many hours (80 hours in 2 weeks) and bought and maxed out pretty much everything. So here is my review:

Reasons not to spend money on it:
- WARNING: External DRM & account registration using UPlay.
- EXTREMELY unbalanced and filled with exploits (I know it's beta). It will most likely be fixed in the future.
- There is no endgame. When you are level 30 on all characters with a full level 30 castle then there is nothing to do. You get no more xp, no use for your resources and ranked play is incredibly unbalanced and unrewarding.
Also buildings like the blacksmith are a joke endgame. Too expensive and the gear is less than what drops on pretty much every run. But again, just balance issues there.
- Magic items with better stats than epic items or legendary weapons with +0 dps but just like 10hp or 10 mana...
- Relatively poor support for steam users (none in fact). [Update: This has changed now and Ubisoft is now also active on the Steam forums]
- Extremely repetitive gameplay.
- Their official forums are regulary filled with spambots for marriage council and flamers. They can't even control their own official forums. Or maybe that was temporary but still...
- Has pretty much the same problems as the (now closed) game Dungeon Empires".
- No co-up. Yes it is 'MMO' but you will never fight against or with another guy. When you attack a castle it all happens client-side and it's basically singleplayer. A hot-seat game has more multiplayer elements than this game.
- Read the forums and such before you spend money in this game! Also wait until you are like level 20 because then you will notice what is really wrong with the game. If you still like it at that point
date: yes do spend money on it.\n- No real ranking system. Totally unbalanced
recommended: even presumably hacked at some occasions
hoursPlayed: and filled with exploits. And even when you rank in the top
voteText: there are no real rewards other than "good job
helpfulPercent:
you exploited everything!"
- And many more reasons.

Updates:
- Currently you can not raid your friends (practice mode only). Will probably be fixed in the future though. [This has been changed and you can now do this a few times / day]
- Common server disconnects. [Mostly fixed by now]

Reasons to spend money on it:
- Early game is really fun.
- Good graphics and great music.
- Has decent humor and an epic trailer.
- Takes you about 50-100 hours to max all characters and castle. So enough gameplay. But the last 50 hours are probably just farming farming and more farming just like raiding the same dungeon in WoW over and over again. Only now it's solo.
- NOT pay-2-win. You only pay for extra characters
votesHelpful:
xp boosts and such and visuals. You might want the characters but aside from that you don't need to buy anything.
But sadly those extra characters are very expensive and if you really like this game then you will need them.
- It's free.


Other reviews that claim that you can "earn" those points ingame... Well.. That will take you months of play before you can even unlock one character that you will then max out in 1-2 days... By running competitions for example it will take you almost exactly 3 months to unlock ONE character. Cheers mate."

reviewText:
The Mighty Quest For Epic Loot is a PvP-driven game where you beset other people's castles and try to steal their riches!

There's not much else to say about it, really. You get loot, you get to pick a class, level up abilities etc. - But overall, i feel that the experience is good for what it is (a F2P). You get some hours of fun out of it.

Later on, people use cheap gimmicks and cheap tactics to make sure you can't raid the castle ; and it becomes painstakingly obvious after a while if you can beat them, and how. Mainly because you do them so many times and it just repeats.

This is not to say that the game is bad - but it gets repetetive with little to no real innovation. Still serves to be a few good hours of entertainment.

Would i recommend it? Yes.

reviewText:
tl;dr - This game gets really ♥♥♥♥ing tedious and P2Wish after a certain point, but if you're willing to put up with that, it's alright.
----------
I have put 21 hours into this game according to Steam, and the only part I started disliking the game was when I reached level 20. At a certain point in the game when you reach the required level, you can purchase 'totems' that prevent creatures from leaving it's radius and healing them on their return. Combine this with Aura Guardians who give damage immunity to all nearby beasties, you have a recipe for a really ♥♥♥♥ing tedious to deal with castle.

And literally everyone is doing it. Literally everyone. Meaning you HAVE to use them yourself to even try and compete with them. Plus, there's really no downside to using them. I've heard people say 'OH BUT THEN YOU CAN WALK PAST THEM' but 9/10 times those people are placing the above setup into chokepoints meaning you HAVE to engage them.

The introduction of the recent 'Infinity Pack' gives you access to all previous content added plus whatever they add in the future. Said pack includes defenses that are arguably the most overpowered in the game. The pack only costs about £15 (at the time of this writing, anyway).

At the end of the day, the game literally just boils down to 'stop making creative layouts, just use totems'.

reviewText: A really good game. It's one of those classic games where you pick your hero and level him up and learn more abilities, but this one adds in more humor, multiplayer, and castle customization. The multiplayer works really well, because you don't get paired against random enemies like in most iPhone and Android games. However, I don't like the way the castle customization works. You should get more traps and monsters as a starting player, because you don't have nearly enough to actually cover much of your castle. I also think that they could change the way the view sorks, because currently you can only view your character from four directions. I think he should be able to be viewed from all possible directions, in a different format from the curent ones.\nOverall, a very pleasant game. It's not one of those games with a really important storyline you have to follow, like Assassin's Creed, where you can't do anything else until you've beaten the game, but there is some story to it you can play.\nGoing to give it a grade similar to those given in school, A-F. A being the best game, F being the worst. I say it's probably a B-, maybe an 8.2/10. It's free, I think, so it's not like it hurts to try it.

reviewText:
With current and upcoming patches the game seems to be progressing in the right direction. Aside from a bit clunky intro, the game runs smoothly and does not has high requestments to properly play it. Leveling seems decent and steady, items in game already have some indepth quite early in game with stats and bonus/special abilities - which makes the game more imersive by giving in another level of gameplay.
Class choise is not gigantic (warrior, mage, archer) and the 4th class that can only be bought makes it a bit questionable over fairness; afterall, a good game is either buy it and have everything included, or be free to play with microtransactions either for consmetic items or boosters of sort (making it so that playing the game is rewarding).
Skill usage in the game is limited to 4 skills per class to use, although player can swap them out for other ones that do him better in certain situations - making a total of 16 skills to pick from for each class. One can also have potions of healing equipped which is always useful. Another good feature the ability to create your own castle. You are given a set of diffrent possible room combinations, given space and 'energy', with which the player can add traps and monsters into it and other players can then raid it. After being attacked, you are then too given the option immediate option to strike your attacker and show him the meaning of raid.
The game might feel a bit like Diablo with camera perspective, health, mana and skill system and ofcourse god-alike monster slaying gameplay. The game is definitely worth trying out, if not else one can relive his awsome Diablo 1 - 2 moments for a whooping cost of 0€.

reviewText:
First of all: It's pay-to-win, like a mobile game.  Definition of pay-to-win: You can spend real money to buy boosts that speed up various aspects of the game, thus putting you ahead of players who don't spend real money.  Pay money and win.  Simple as that.

That said, it's actually pretty fun.  It combines the hacking and/or slashing of Diablo with the dungeon building of Dungeon Keeper.  Looting and crafting is simple yet addictive.  In fact, simple yet addictive" is a perfect tagline for the whole game.

I haven't spent any real money on the game but I'm still having a good time with it.  Your results may vary."

reviewText: This fun game will have you captivated for hours as you raid other player's Castle's and upgrade your own defense's to keep out would be attackers. It's a mix of Diablo style hack'n'slash mixed with a kind of 3D tower defense. The game is in beta and to be honest I think that was a bit rushed, it would feel better having it tagged as Alpha still. That being said there are a few main things to be dealt with gameplay wise before the game will be something that I consider complete. My best guess is that at current time it is going to be 6 months out before this is a polished game. It is still very fun to play even with the couple design flaws present. And I think most people will not even be as tight about those issue's as I am. You'll need to hit level 16 to really start seeing those things, but for the most part I think the game is pretty great.\n\nTake care when reading negative reviews that they are not outdated. When the game first hit open beta there were a few flaws that got fixed quickly but there were a lot of reviews in the negative based on that.

It will certainly entertain those in need of a quick gaming fix, but won’t replace games like Diablo in your library anytime soon.The Mighty Quest for Epic Loot is a pretty good game that is just so much fun to play whether you are diving head first into someone’s Castle or if you are working on your own Castle’s defences and trying to get things just right.This is a fresh experience in the free-to-play scene, even though we need to wait and see whether Ubisoft offers enough support to make our time feel well spent on it.

Build your castle, fill it with traps and monsters, watch enemy heroes invading it. Invade enemy castles with your hero, evade traps, kill everything and loot treasures. Level up hero, learn abilities, buy items, sets, potions. Buy and craft new traps and stronger guardians for your castle, build new rooms and mazes.

reviewText:
For me the dungeon design game isn't dead, just usually poorly implemented. If you are a fan of Dungeon Keeper or Evil Genius take note: this game is legit. Don't believe me? Try it out it's free. With no risk. You can get quite far into Mighty Quest before you decide if this is the game for you.

In the end I decided that it was, and I even picked out a couple of bundle packs to buy to support the game and improve my game experience. The graphics, music, sound, sarcastic one liners are all well executed and will keep you coming back for more. You will marvel at the designs of other players that completely thwart your attempts to rob them all the while attempting to make those perfect castle layouts. You'll howl when they break through your defenses and hit the drawing board in minutes with new ideas.

Very fun game, I've been waiting for something like this for a LONG time.

reviewText: The idea was truly amazing. It is very exciting to have a bunch of notifications on your screen, check all the playbacks of players trying to loot your castle and fail. Or succeed. It makes the whole process of improving your castle very entertaining. But the truth is, there's no place for improvement in the end game. Unless you open your wallet to ubisoft. All the most powerful traps, monsters, weapons and gear are only obtained by paying money. After a while, raiding high level castles becomes impossible. It's not even a case of putting a lot of hours into a game for a chance to obtain some powerful items or monsters for your castle. No money, no honey. It really ruins the whole experience and what could have been an amazing game. And the community literally died a long time ago. Big dissapointment.

-Very Repetitive

CONCLUSION
I can actually see people liking and disliking this game. Ubisoft has made many great games and this one is OK. It sure isn't amazing but it isn't terrible either.

6/10

reviewText:
[This was written 11-Feb.-2014, so the nature of alpha and beta reviews is that they quickly become obsolete. The portions written on the attack portion of the game still hold relatively the same, but updates have rendered my comments completely void for the defensive section. I have no intention of playing this game again, so take this review as it is, a timely, but potentially expired review.]

This game breaks down two two gameplay systems, and either can reasonably be played independant of the other. The first is attacking castles, be it the castles made by the developers to allow world progression, or be it other player's castles. The second is a tower defence style mmo, where you must setup creatures and traps to prevent other players from completing your castle within a time limit (or all together). Based on my experience, whether you enjoy the attack portion of this system largely decides how much enjoyment you get from the game.

The attack portion of the game plays much like I imagine Diablo plays, and I say I 'imagine' because I've never had a remote incling to play any Diablo game. The control style is structured so that to move somewhere you click there, and to attack something you click on it. There are also special abilities that have area or effect damage, or line-style piercing, and these are assigned to keys. My problem with this is that I've never found that control style even remotely fun. So, take that as you will: If you like Diablo, you may like the attack portion, and if not then perhaps not.

The attack portion becomes very skill-based very quickly, and you'll quickly notice that often you don't stand a chance of defeting some of the player dungeons at your level when that player has competancy in how to setup their castle. That's not to say that you can't beat castles; by and large most players just haven't learned how to properly setup a dungeon to actually defeat a skilled attacker, at least in lower levels. One reason this becomes a real hinderance, is that the player's leveling is dependent on a tower that must be built in the defensive part of the game. This means that essentially, unless the player spends a significant time also playing the defensive portion, they hit a level cap, and basically can't progress any further attacking, and this is where the game is really held back by being free to play"/"pay to win"/"free to wait."

The defensive portion of the game follows a fairly simple concept of tower defence. But
date: instead of a standard tower defence game where you build towers until some tower-unit cap is reached
recommended: that naturally gets progressively larger as the player "wins" and progresses through the game
hoursPlayed: the tower-unit cap is based again on other towers
voteText: like the attacking level cap tower. So
helpfulPercent: to progress
votesHelpful: the player must spend gold upgrading this tower that governs the other towers
votesTotal: which are limited by the level of other towers
votesFunny: which are limited by the level of other towers
commentsCount: which are limited by the level of other towers
column16: and so on. So the defensive game boils down to upgrading one tower so that other towers can be upgraded
column17: so that other towers can be upgraded
column18: until ultimately the actual defensive towers (or creatures for this game) can actually be upgraded. This would be fine
column19: except the game is "free to play"/"pay to win"/"free to wait
column20: so any time a tower is designated for an upgrade, this upgrade comes with a countdown timer until the upgrade is completed. This in principle is okay, except that the upgrade countdown times quickly reach into the hours, and from there into even full days.\n\nSo, the game ends up being this thing where you log in, do as much as you can until you reach these limits, and have to either stop playing the game, or pay real money for the third currency, which allows for instant completion of any upgrade. This would be okay in principle if not for the extremely excessive countdown times, but the prices required for these intsant upgrades are fairly steep, and quicly reach prices in the dollars for single upgrades. Seems a bit like a price gouge to me. Maybe the expectation is that the top 1% of players will basically pay for the rest of the players, but if that were the case the countdowns shouldn't get so high so quickly, to that point that they actually become prohibitive of gameplay. The game is like many other free-to-play" games
column21: and seemigly has the sole goal of extracting money from the player
column22: not actually being enjoyable.\n\nIf given to you by a friend
column23: give the game a try. If it's still free when you read this and you're still interested
column24: give it a try. But no one in their right mind should pay a dime to get the game in the first place
column25: and no-one but the rich should spend any money on the third currency until you know you actually like the game enough to do so.\n\nEDIT: I uninstalled this game right after writing this review because honeslty
column26: I'm tired of waiting to not have fun."

reviewText:
Despite the fact that the game is going to give those that put money into it a real advantage in their castles, This game is really fun.

I haven't put money in the game personally, and i have a decent set-up, ( I Think) anyway, with just the ingame currency i have grinded.

The game itself has 3 types of currency,

Gold, Standard currency in most games, easily grindable from other dungeons.
Crystals, A secondary currency that goes hand in hand with gold again easily grindable.
Bling (emeralds) These things are the pay to win currency that most games like this have, You can buy material packs to build monsters, Increase inventory space after the 2nd tab. Buy special pets and cosmetic items.

You can use your gold to buy equipment, and most upgrades to your hero and castle, But of course Bling is easier if your willing to pay for that stuff.


All in all A great game, Not a new concept but wonderfully executed, love the dialogue from the characters and the art and music is wonderful :) i say 4/5 stars would be 5 ive the prices in game for items weren't so expensive via gold as apposed to Bling.

reviewText:
Hack and slash through your friends castles or raid your enemies in this simple PvP/RPG.

You set up your own fortress, customizing the rooms and monsters you wish to place inside them. You are also allowed to rig traps throughout your domain to kill, maim or humiliate your opponents.

No pay to win and the game is very fair. Shields are placed when you have been raided, preventing resources from being stolen for a certain amount of time, most commonly 12hours. To prevent people from making impossible mazes, you must verify your own maze by completing it yourself.

Craft or find your own gear, attacking player castles or NPC castles to gain lifeforce, gold and experience so that you can make an inpenatrable fortress of awesomeness.

I found the game very fun at first, but I slowly lost interest due to most players using the same defense tactics, spam a certain powerful archer or place instant kill bomb traps covered by flame mortars. The game itself has decent replay value, but it can feel like you aren't getting anywhere at times. If you have the time and patiance, have at thee.

Personal Rating: 3/5

reviewText:
I'm not sure about this game. After playing until level 10, it has fun elements. It's great fun to raid other people's castles. Upgrading units and trying to make your castle tough to beat is fun!

One of the major issues I have with this game, is the castle vaidation. It's one thing to validate your castle after you added monsters, but also after adding extra mines or moving monsters is really annoying.

Haven't found a Pay to Win aspect as of yet, since there is no real PvP in the game. Sure you can level faster or gain gold/life force (another currency) faster, but that's not a big deal. For now I will recommend this game, let's see how it develops in the future.

reviewText:
A few hours into the game, at level 9 or so, it does not seem as bad as many reviews would have it seem.  The game is definitely a grind, but there doesn't seem to be any way to buy a victory.  Spending money gets you additional classes, and XP and resource boosts, which just serve to make the grind shorter.

I will say this, the game is definitely still in beta territory, but it is also free, so it is hard to come down to roughly on the problems the game has.  Those problems are mostly balance issues.  AI Aggro is very weird and not explained at all within the game itself, and there are a bunch of things with regards to castle building that are basically never really explained to the player in any detail.   The controls are also excrutiatingly frustrating to deal with right now.   The build controls feel completely unintuitive and just plain unsensible sometimes, and the combat controls feel awkward if you are coming off of Diablo 3, especially since so many of the abilities are extremely similar.  You end up taking damage when you don't mean to because things don't really work as smoothly as they do in D3.

If they can fix the AI and overall balance and controls, this game would be a HUGE winner.  It's already fun in its beta state.

I'd give it a C+ currently.  IF they fix the issues it would be a solid A.   For free, however, it is totally recommendable.

reviewText: The game engine works smooth.  The graphics look nice.   The action is fast and pleasurable.  The gameplay feels outstanding but everything you do really means nothing in the game since ultimately your score is based on how many easy castles you beat and how many times a low ranked person beats your castle not how good a player you are.  Leaderboards are very easy to manipulate since you can have your friends intentionally lose to you or create extra accounts to sandbag and steal large amounts of crowns from your competitors.\n\nI won't recommend against the game since its fun to play casually for awhile but I wouldn't spend much if any money on this.

2 Things about this game.

1) It reminds me of Evil Genius with the humor slashed with Dungeon Keeper.

2) Pay to Win. If you have a level 5 castle with only level 30 stuff in it and your heroes are level 11 then thats pay to win,
if you buy the infinite pack to support the creators of the game ( same as buying a game that cost $20) then you're helping support the game devs. And it's not considered pay to win.

In the future I suggest the game creators make something to the effect that alows players ways to ban or ignore others who leave nasty comments on castles or spam attack you over and over just to change the comments.

reviewText:
This game is an absolute must have if your into games like Dungeon Defenders or if you like Tower Defense games, I came into the game with a mindset that this would be completely pay to win.. I was wrong, it turns out that the microtransactions are actually not as overpowered as most free to play games, people can spend real life money to upgrade their mines or structures if they can't afford it with in-game currency and free to play players aren't really held back in terms of paying to have fun either, I've only just bought some blings earlier today because I wanted to buy a machine that creates 10 materials each day, you'd think people could just buy loads of them and have unlimited materials... well guess what, they've thought of that and allowed every castle to have only 1 Material Machine, this game isn't pay to win it's more like pay for convenience.

There is so much I could say about this game, but I want to keep it short. This game is free and it's the most fun I've had with a free to play game for a long time.

8/10 - There's no reason to not get it.

reviewText: This is a pretty interesting game. It plays like a Diablo-like, but you fight exclusively in either pre-made castles, or castles made by other players. Other players can attack your castle and steal some of your gold and life force, but it's never a crippling amount, and it can be more than made up by playing one level, or attacking your attacker back. The castle building is relatively easy to use, place monsters, traps, etc, rearrange the rooms in your castle and add more to make it more difficult. The game is fun, but like a lot of other F2P games, progression slows down a lot after the first 10 or so levels. However, the game avoids being Pay to Win by selling pretty much exclusively cosmetic items. There are one or two barracade items you buy for the premium currency, but the Pay 2 Win of that is avoided in that the owner of a castle needs to be able to clear it themselves before others can play it, and their clear time is the time you need to beat. TL;DR, Give the game a shot, it's free, and it's fun.

reviewText: The Mighty Quest for Epic Loot is a Free-to-Play title from Ubisoft Montreal that thrusts you in an outrageous medieval fantasy world called Opulencia where wealth, status and showboating are the name of the game!\n\nUsing intuitive construction tools, players will construct mighty castles of their own devious creation, designed to protect their precious treasure. By filling it to the brim with deadly monsters and traps, this castle will ensure that any would-be looters will think twice before setting foot inside. Players will also partake in looting of their own by pitting their own powerful hero against Opulencia’s most legendary keeps, using deep hack ‘n slash gameplay controls. The Mighty Quest for Epic Loot is asynchronous, meaning you don’t have to be connected at the same time as your friends or adversary to be playing with them.

reviewText:
Great game, great loot! Tons of customization for your castle, and it feels great when your castle kills another player!

This game has a lot of people complaining about p2w....
Every game that is free to play is going to have an aspect where the developers receive money for a player benefit.(You are an idiot if you do work and don't ask for compensation) People always troll around saying all these games are P2W, but it's not at all. You either pay for a video game, or you play a free video game and if you like it, you pay for some extra gear. Why is everyone so butthurt about playing a free video game? These people need to get their brains checked.

I've played this game for a few days and I have yet to pay a dime to the developers,AND I have almost all epic gear on my archer, my castle is ~30% wins which isn't bad, and no one has ever beaten my time. I don't have a boss yet but it takes time to farm the appropriate crafting materials, which makes sense, otherwise every room would have a boss in it. Once your castle is plundered and some of your loot is stolen, you are automatically defended for a certain amount of time so other players can't steal your loot, they can just enjoy running the castle. And if you play one or two castles which takes about 5 minutes, you can make all the loot you lost back and then some.

Tip #1 for new players, Traps are almost always what kills people, don't focus on monsters, just focus on traps.
Tip # 2 - if you are placing monsters, place them near an entry way with a totem so the enemy player can't kite them down the hall.
Tip #3 - To get epic loot, you NEED to beat the enemy times and kill all the mines. For the most part the monsters will chase you so just focus on finding the mines first and then kill the monsters. If you don't have to kill a monster, just run by it, if there is a red dot on your mini map, it means he's seen you and you DO need to kill him.

Overall, great game, I've definitely put in enough hours already to justify kicking some money to the devs, and I'm thinking I might just to troll the trolls.

reviewText:
L2P2W -> Learn to pay to win...

Creativity is hard to find; most use the same combinations of traps / creatures.
These combinations are reserved for people who pay real money to play the game (or had endless time to gind since the earliest Alpha release).

Now, here's the real kicker ->  Where you normally pay € 60 for a AAA game title, getting the DLC for this game will set you back € 85 (Infinite pack + Gold Defender pack, so that's only if you don't buy ingame currency, then it goes to a total of € 145). [Sounds like ciminal behavior to me; Fraud, Attempted Theft / Robbery, Highly misleading advertising, etc].

In all fairness; the game was quite fun up to hero level 18 or so...
So if you want a free game for a weekend or so, I'd say take this one!
If you want a game to invest time in; there are MUCH better games with much more to offer!
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
this game is monumentally flawed. the most challenging part is to master what is normally considered basic. moving your character. controlling the camera. this game has failed at the basics.

yet i still find myself playing. i think the challenge of overcoming such a fundamental and overpowering failure of design is what drives me to keep trying.

I admit as I reach the highest level in this very typical pay to win game the frustration of poor design combined with no hope for advancement makes this game look very short lived for my future entertainment. 45 hrs in and just about done

reviewText: An interesting, fun, and addicting game, but littered with microtransactions that give members who spend money an upper hand. Classic Ubisoft.
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game starts out being very enjoyable. I spent hours and hours customizing my castle to try and get the best defense possible. However, after awhile, running through other people's castles gets really repetitive, and I feel like the NPC castles are just there to advance you to higher levels.

Running through a castle filled entirely with chickens (which are extremely easy to kill) is funny the first few times, but eventually I found myself getting tired of avoiding the same traps and killing the same enemies over and over again, because at certain levels, there are only so many options available to the player to customize their castle defense with.

To be fair, I never reached the really high levels of the game, but the gameplay just became too monotonous for me to want to play that long, and I didn't want to spend a ton of money just to get ahead.

Because it's free, you can't really go wrong at least giving it a try. I started out with one of the booster packs just to try and give myself a headstart, but even that doesn't really mask the fact that if you want to create something unique and/or progress through the game quickly, you'll soon find that the only way to effectively do that is to buy your way through via the in-game purchases.

reviewText:
Ok, this is my first review, so dont get angry.
First:

NOTE: THIS IS EARLY GAME REVIEW

--Gameplay--
+Easy to learn
+Having fun blowing everything to pieces
+haven't seen a single bug since the alpha/beta
-Not addictive*
-Not worth attacking enemies from your level.
-If you bought the game in the beta, all the AI/Mobs were bought with gold, now you need to craft them, the beta-mobs are so weak, its not fun playing to a player who quit the game. (you can still buy them, but thats not really worthed)
-/+Pets dont really have something usefull exept picking up loot. (choose if that is a good or a bad thing)
*This is almost your standard facebook game, only now you can fight, its just like: Ok, now i collect my gold/crystal mines, now upgrade something and you can wait 6 hours again before you get something.
this is not a big problem, if it was addicting, you dont feel like this: i need to be back in 4 hours to collect my gold; ok ill be online then. like you feel in farmville or candy crush or whatever.

--Controls--
+Moba controls
+Abillity with numbers
+I was very happy with the control settings at start

--Balance--
-You don't know from the start of a raid if it is hard or easy.
-Really unbalanced in Abillity/minion (To easy to kill everything in early game)
-It costs to much to upgrade your castle, and it is just not really worthed

--Sounds--
+Good sound, nothing much to say really
-At start R.I.P. Headphone knight users

--Graphics--
NOTE: opinion
(I play games for the gameplay, not for the graphics. maybe if it was a P2P game, like me in the beta i would juge them, but for a F2P i don't.)
+It doesn't have bad graphics

--First impression--
Your basic Facebook game,
Only fighting, crafting and graphics better.
Don't play this game for the strategy!
You will be disliking the early gameplay.
The early gameplay is about grinding and grinding the castles of enemy players.
Patience = Everything

--CONCLUSION--
+Fun to play for half an Hour P/day
+Easy to learn
+First time spening RL Money In a game got me something Worthed (Material o' Matic)
+F2P!
-I paid for the beta
-Miss the addictive part*
-Boring after playing longer than a hour
-where is the balance in this game?!

Who ordered the offline-TP-Onelane-FacebookVersion of a moba?
When you get the game for money => 4/10
When you get the game for free  => 6.5/10

Sorry for my bad english, this is my first review.
Hope you liked it!

reviewText: I recommend this game because it's free and fun when you start playing. Unfortunately the game gets dull and repetative after soon after you finish the tutorail levels. This is because there is not much variety in enemy and trap types, and while designing you own castle seemed cool at the time there isn't much you can do to make yours special. And because  of the games validation system in wich you have to beat your own castle to make it valid there is very little challenge in beating players the same level as you, and if it is hard for some reason you can just attack castle three levels lower than you. There are four classes of heroes and you start with one for free then you have use the premium currency to unlock other classes. This wouldn't be a problem if each class had lots of abilities and ways to play. This is not the case, i chose archer and he shoots arrows, and has abilities that let him shoot better arrows, and he has a pet hawk who can attack enemies. This lack of branching makes for a rather boring character. I also had a free trial of the knight class, he can hit things, and has abilities that let him hit things in arcs and hit things hard. Again not much variance. Ontop of this you need a Uplay account, I already had one from Far Cry 3 but I know some people hate Uplay with all their heart lungs and kidneys. So i reccomend it because it's free and fun for the first few hours, but it does get repetitive

reviewText:
I have been playing this game off and on since early beta.  It has gone through a LOT of changes, and only recently can I actually recommend this game.

It started off many months ago as an unfun time sink Hell.  Want to do anything?  Set it going and come back a long long long time from then.  It got worse the further you progressed.  Not fun, I stopped playing.

Not so many months ago I heard the mechanics completely changed, so I checked it out.  Holy crap pay to win doesn't even begin to cover it.  Stopped playing.

The Infinite Pack got me scratching my head.  I tried the game again as a free player and realized it's not a free to play game.  It's a demo with no end, just gimped.  Was it still pay to win?  It seemed so on the surface, but I dug deeper.  I tried looking at it such that the Infinite Pack was actually buying the game.  You get all past and future content to some degree?  No extra money sink required?  Sounds pretty good.  So I went for it.  A few more hours of gameplay later I came to a conclusion about if it's pay to win or not.

What can you buy with real money?  Cosmetics, crafting material packs, and rare monsters.  I am all for paying real money for cosmetic items.  Fully support that business model and hundreds of dollars to Path of Exile proves it.  Crafting material packs allow you to get dumps of mats to craft your normally available monsters.  Monsters even available to free players.  The materials are all gatherable by free players by raiding castles.  Not pay to win, but definitely pay for convenience.

What about buying rare monsters?  Here's the rub.  If you consider the Infinite Pack the cost of the game you get quite a few already.  Can more be bought?  Sure.  Are they available to free players?  Not reasonably.  Sounds like pay to win.  But the devs did try to balance it.  For instance, your castle is limited to a certain number of monsters, and further, you're limited on how tightly you can pack those monsters.  All elite monsters won't save a horrible defense design.  But the strategic level of skill player with and without elite monsters will do slightly better with elite.  To further balance this the devs applied a loot-o-meter.  The more rare monsters in your defense, the higher the chance you'll drop rare loot.  This means more people will want to attack you.  Or, if you're a kindly person you can arrange a poor defense purposely and increase the loot drops for anyone visiting.

All things said, I've got about 10 hours played since the Infinite Pack came out and I have yet to encounter anything that was clearly unbalanced towards pay players.  But then, I'm not in the top tiers of end game yet, either.  I just have fun with the 2-3 minute mini dungeon runs and seeing what creative things people have come up with.  I purposely undo the shield on my castle that protects me from attackers just to get more people to visit and see how they handle it.

If it took longer to run castles I would be less pleased with the game, but in bite sized chunks it can be a blast.

reviewText:
I've been playing this game for the first time this last week or 2 and have found it quite enjoyable. Yes, you need a youplay account, but Ive already had it for other games and have never had an issue with it in any way. It just opens when you want to play the game and you can close it afterwards. Never has it crashed a game while playing for me.

You start out building up your castle and attacking others to earn money and such to make yours better. While you can pay to get bonus things, I have not spent a dime and am at lvl 15 and still having a blast. To make more creatures you find drops while fighting others monsters and you can craft things that way. You can level up almost everything you have as you go like your inventory, gold storage. When you attack others castles, they make it so you can stay at your own level of rank as to not be defeated as soon as you enter. Some are trickier then others so may take some extra time leveling up your little guy so he has better attack and defense items.

I really do enjoy this game and Im sure many others will too. As always, take all reviews with a grain of salt and try it for yourself. Its a very detailed game and does have a very nice tutorial as you go through it first so pay attention so you dont forget simple tasks. :D Have fun!

reviewText: To be honest, I love this game to pieces. It truly is a good game, it has addictive gameplay, enjoyable characters and more. But my only real problem with it is the OBVIOUS pay to win side of it. Yes, it's possible to beat them without paying, but that's not my point. What I'm saying is this, most bosses have a weak side to them. Except for the one I've been stuck on for ages. Captain Clubbage, you can also get him as a boss in your castle. In my opinion he is blatantly overpowered. No joke, you can't stun him, at all. As a knight if you are around the same level, you are screwed. Because he can, clone himself, teleport, take a ♥♥♥♥ ton of damage, has long AND close range attacks. And moves at a pace that can keep up with the hero. Now, as fun as this game is, having a boss such as that. That can be payed for very simply kind of irks me. As I said, I do like this game. But there are some massive balancing issues that need to be attended to. Hell, to test my theory I use a knight and then an archer which were both 4 levels higher than my friends castle. Both were able to easily get through it until he had his Captain Clubbage come after me. I dunno, maybe I'm overreacting. But it kind of ruins an entire portion of the game for me, knowing a level 10 can have this guy by spending a few dollars. I mean, even bosses that are HIGHER levels than him are easier to defeat. So the tl;dr version is. It has some major balancing issues that maybe need to be looked at. That and it has as many microtransactions as Candy Crush. (That was a joke. A bad one.) So that wraps up my opinion, but if I were to give it a score. 8.7/10. It's good, but can do better with a bit of tweaking.

reviewText: I recommend this game because it's free and fun when you start playing. Unfortunately the game gets dull and repetative after soon after you finish the tutorail levels. This is because there is not much variety in enemy and trap types, and while designing you own castle seemed cool at the time there isn't much you can do to make yours special. And because  of the games validation system in wich you have to beat your own castle to make it valid there is very little challenge in beating players the same level as you, and if it is hard for some reason you can just attack castle three levels lower than you. There are four classes of heroes and you start with one for free then you have use the premium currency to unlock other classes. This wouldn't be a problem if each class had lots of abilities and ways to play. This is not the case, i chose archer and he shoots arrows, and has abilities that let him shoot better arrows, and he has a pet hawk who can attack enemies. This lack of branching makes for a rather boring character. I also had a free trial of the knight class, he can hit things, and has abilities that let him hit things in arcs and hit things hard. Again not much variance. Ontop of this you need a Uplay account, I already had one from Far Cry 3 but I know some people hate Uplay with all their heart lungs and kidneys. So i reccomend it because it's free and fun for the first few hours, but it does get repetitive

reviewText:
This game has a lot of potential but suffers from repetition in a small but significant way. The game it great mostly, you build your castle, you place creatures and traps to defend it and you raid castles made by other players. Wonderful idea and had me playing for hours searching for defense flaws and leveling up my character. It does have some kind of pay to win aspect but more than anything it speeds up the building of your castle. Nothing over powered like some players portray it, only a momentum boost.

Once I reached the higher levels though, I found myself sick of playing the game as nothing new was happening. Harder castles but same raiding style. On top of that my castle was barely getting any attention from other players even with my high defense rating. I was praying that more people would attempt to break my defenses but no. The game is still in Beta so do expect bugs and more importantly exciting updates.

Seeing this is a free to play game I highly suggest that you try it out! But overall this is a great game for all ages with lots of potential for the future.

reviewText:
If you took Diablo 3 and any Tower Defense game and mashed them together the child they would give up for adoption would be The Mighty Quest For Epic Loot.   I went into this game with low expectations since I really didn't think a F2P game could do a hack and slash loot game very well.  I was surprised and I played 16 hours the first day without realizing it.

Pros:  You just have to give it a chance and not expect the moon and the stars.  It is fun to attack other people's castles as you level up your character and collect loot and having to choose between spending in-game currency on your character or on your castle (to improve defenses) is a nice twist.  The tower defense part (where other players attack your castle) is a lot of fun too since you can watch the replays of every attempt to break in.

Cons:  Non-customisable key bindings is kind of a huge problem for me since I have hand issues to do a medical condition and it's a pain to reach all the way to the number keys to do my spells.  Also not being able to access your inventory while in a castle is kind of silly.

reviewText: This game is actually quite a bit of fun. While the dungeon building may be a little weak if you don't want to spend money (The most powerful stuff is avaliable only through crafting or 'bling', which is tedious and/or costly). It makes up for it at least most of the way in my mind through the Revenge option, which allows you to raid the castle of a player who bested yours.\n\nIt's got a surprising amount of depth for what it is. Still, it's not at all a game to be taken too seriously, and frankly, if you find the pay to win aspects to be unbearable, you're probably taking it too seriously. I find it fits nicely in a not too casual, not too hardcore niche.

reviewText:
On one side, you design your castle with monsters and traps [Dungeon Keeper] and on the other side, you attack other people's castles [Diablo].

Attacking a castle will take less than 5 minutes, but it's an intense experience that Diablo fans will certainly love. Designing your castle will please Defense Tower lovers. And it's free, you can't ask for much more...

But once you reach the higher levels, you realize that the paid content is much, much deadlier (3-4 times deadlier) than the best monsters/traps you can buy or craft with the ingame currencies. You can still attack other castles with almost even chances, but your castle will be a walk in the park for your opponents, unless you buy the premium traps and monsters, with real money. And the more you buy, the deadlier your castle will be.

I really shouldn't complain, I have enjoyed this game for free during some time, but I can't help feeling cheated on. I wouldn't mind paying for the game, as I have done with many other games, but I don't want to enter the circle of paying more and more to stay in the game. I don't want to have a great castle just because I paid for it.

I also wouldn't mind forgetting about my castle and focusing on attacking other people, but this is also spoiled at higher levels, when you start finding impassable castles overstuffed with deadly fire and acid traps. You also find the same castle setups over and over, and the once thrilling experience now becomes repetitive and boring.

Conclusion: great at lower levels and fails at higher levels. Overall, I think it's better to dedicate you time to other game that won't disappoint you.

reviewText:
Interesting concept, not so well executed
(keep in mind I haven't played for a while so stuff may be outdated)
Alright this'll be a short review, some things I want to talk about are:
Class system
Loot system
Towers build by the game self
Towers build by players

-Class system
At the start of the game you can pick 3 characters, 4 if you pay real money. The classes are
archer
warrior
wizard (so original)
I'm not going to bother about the fourth class, seeing how little people buy classes with real money

-Loot system
The loot system isn't terrible, you kill enemies and they drop stuff. You can also buy loot from the shop (no need for real life money, ingame cash will do) luckly you can sell loot you don't need

-Towers build by the game self
Towers build by the game self are usually pretty reasonable, you may have to try 2 or 3 times, but then you're good. The main problem is there isn't nearly enough of these towers, seeing as most are build by players. Thanks to this it's really hard to level up and get to other castles.

-Towers build by players
This isn't an issue with the game or by developers self, this is purely thanks to the players. 90% of the players don't try to make a clever dungeon that's hard to crack. They just spam the biggest and strongest enemy 100x. I know the game can't help this, but it's really annoying, because it just turns the game into a grind fest.

Overal I'd probably give this game a 5/10, because it gets stale really fast.

reviewText:
The Mighty Quest For Epic Loot is a fun and unique game that is at least worth playing and trying out since it is free and everything, but there are some design decisions that prevent it from being a truly amazing game.

The main problem is with creating a defense for your castle. More than half of all traps and creatures are completely useless when you get to the end of the game, especially when the rare weekly ones are so much better than what you normally have access to. To make it worse, the game is geared towards making it easy for raiders, such as being able to consistently disable entire rooms of traps, getting time bonuses just for destroying objects, and healing for a lot just by using normal attacks. Unless you're a top 10 dungeon, it is rather pointless spending any time defending your dungeon since you will more than likely always lose to raiders, and you gain so much more from raiding constantly.

Video showing some gameplay:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9r-GGeLHzqw

Follow my curator list for future early access game recommendations:
http://store.steampowered.com/curator/6856568-Should-You-Play-This-Game/

reviewText:
TLDR at bottom.

Okay... this is a tough one. There is nothing like this game out there, it's one of a kind, which keeps me coming back.

Craft a castle of your style, arrange rooms, place monsters, and place traps to ward off attacking players.  Players can attack you at will, and if they successfully defeat your castle without dying, they will attain a percentage of your saved resources.

These resources are what you use to craft monsters, traps, upgrade machinery, and buy various things. You get these resources from beating enemy player castles, killing monsters in those castles, and you also get resources from mines" that you place in your castle... which brings me to the first gripe of this game.

This game has a distinct mobile feeling to it. In order to reliably attain resources
date: you place "mines" in your castle to farm them while you are away from the game
recommended: or doing other things. You click on these mines once every few hours to obtain the resources they have collected. You can spend in game gold to upgrade these "mines" making them farm more per hour. (Think clash of clans style). The menu's don't feel very intuitive
hoursPlayed: and how you navigate everywhere.  It feels like the whole game was designed to be released on mobile.\n\nSpeaking of mobile... This game is blantantly pay to win. You can play this entire game without paying a cent
voteText: reach max level
helpfulPercent: craft an intricate castle with many rooms. However
votesHelpful: you will be extremely angry when attacking other players and seeing some traps
votesTotal: monsters
votesFunny: and bosses you cannot obtain. Even with the in game cash currency (Blings)
commentsCount: some of these are only purchasable using real money. These traps
column16: monsters
column17: and bosses do feel overpowered
column18: and really hurt. In a way
column19: I am glad they offer a package to obtain most of these unattainable items. The $15.00 "Infinity" pack contains all these bosses
column21: and barricades. If you want to enjoy this game to the fullest
column22: you're going to want to fork over 15$. The amount of frustration of experiencing this game without being able to get the strongest thing is really unbelievable.\n\nI've been playing this since early alpha
column23: the game has changed a lot. The final system they arrived on is one that pushes the player to purchase in game currency to buy "Material" packs to craft items. Materials is a second component used
column24: the second being life force or gold
column25: to craft in game creatures. There are so many of these materials that it makes farming for them impossible. You simply go to other players castles and hope you get the type of material you want.\nSome creatures take over 20 or 30 of a certain material
column26: and when there are so many that you can receive
column27: it makes it extremely frustrating trying to get what you need. On average you receive probably 1 common material per run
column28: while rare and higher grade materials being much rarer.\n\nThe "loot" in this game isn't very special. Despite the game name
column29: loot is not very interesting. You gear up your player similar to any RPG and this makes him stronger and able to fight higher level castles. They look uninteresting
column30: and are very very uninspired. It would be much more interesting to find loot for your castles with random modifiers and things like that. You end up raiding castles not for any loot
column31:
but for gold and life force to increase your castles capabilities. The gear you get is often just sold for this.

So why play this game?

There is nothing quite like it. There is nothing like watching replays of people attempting to raid your castle
column32:
and watching them feel miserably at a spot in your castle you specifically set up to be challenging with a devilish set of traps and monsters that work very well together.

You can enjoy the game for quite a while until you hit a point where you realize that you are gimped and don't want to play anymore without having to spend real money.

TLDR: I am giving this a recommendation because this game is an experience that you won't get in any other game. You can play for a long time until you feel like you need to spend money. It's shamelessly pay to win
column33: but until someone remakes a game with this style (which would be AMAZING)
column34:
you have to get this experience here.
Please someone make a game with this concept that is deeper and more intricate without pay to win mechanics. I would pay a lot of money for a game without microtransactions like this.

Pros:
Unique concept
column35:
competitive dungeon keeper
Watching replays of people getting destroyed by your castle

Cons:
Material system makes you REALLY want to buy material packs
column36:
or farm for days on end for a single creature you want
Real money required to get certain things
Feels like it was meant to be a mobile game
Boring loot
Boring combat
Ubisoft"

reviewText: This is an awesome mix of dungeon diving and tower defense to an extent. You can customize your castle and you do so in a way to keep other players from reaching your Core" and if they do then they complete your castle and leave with whatever they looted from your castle. The stronger the monsters and traps you put in your castle the harder you can make it for the players that enter your castle. The higher you make your character's level and your castle level the more monsters and traps you have available to you. There is a cash shop but everything you can get in the cash shop you can get from crafting or buying in the in game store with gold and life force which is the in game currancy. Bling is also an in game currancy which you gain very slowly. If you plan on making this one of your main games i recommend buying the infinite pack which allows you to buy just about everything for 1 gold under the infinite tab of the in game shop.\n\n"

reviewText: I've never really seen the problem with the way this game implements its monetary system. I remember the days when I would drop 40-60$ on a console game. you can Buy" this game for forty dollars by getting the infinite pack. If you don't have the money then you can save up bling (which is actually a lot more plentiful then people make it sound) to buy a bling mine and start getting it passively.\n\nAlso
date: for all the people complaining about finding crafting mats. Once you get into the late game there are passive enchantments on almost every item to give you an increased rate of rare item drops. I have a huge stockpile of epic crafting material for the next unique creature/trap that gets released.\n\nThe real fun lies in the castle development. I have over 250 hours logged just since it came out on steam. I log on almost daily to see all the people my castle has destroyed. People constantly scream "pay to win" after running mine
recommended: even though the vast majority of my dungeon I grinded for like most other people.\n\nTo close
hoursPlayed: for me the real gem in this game is sticking it out to the late game when all your hours lead to you having an amazingly over powered dungeon."

reviewText:
I love this game. I know it's kind of pay2win, but i love Mighty Quest because of the music, the feels, the weird lines the heroes keep saying... I love this game because of it's community.
The game keeps updating what's a good thing, and the creators/hosts of this game put a lot of work in it, and it's visible in alot of these updates. They listen to the players, the poeple who love this game, but comments are welcome too appearantly.
Sad thing is the fact that i'm not really rich or have too much time so it's hard to keep up with all of the better players. And many of MQFEL players have this same issue.
But aside from the worse aspects i really recommend this game. For it's humor, it's community and for the experience as a whole.

Thanks Dev's. =P

reviewText: The Mighty Quest For Epic Loot is nothing more like Clash of Clans but on PC. It's a Free to Play game where you have a castle and defend your loot from other players with traps and monsters. The tedious part is when you prepare your castle because of the following reasons: 1. You have to make sure that it's set up properly 2. It can't be impossible to raid (I'll tell you why in a bit) and 3. You have to do a test run in order that your castle is POSSIBLE to raid. If you die a lot during that process, it's either because it's impossible to raid it or your lack of skills.\n\nMy conclusion is that it's a good game to play but it gets rather tedious.

reviewText:
When I started playing the game I quickly knew that I liked the game and wanted to invest $25 into it to get the Infinite Package.

After paying for that I haven't needed to 'pay2win', since the Infinite Package comes with a bunch of goodies including a mine that creates premium currency.  Other than that, casual gaming and kicking butt will earn you all the loot you need.  I've spend my premium currency that my mine produces to buy bragging aesthetic items, like flaming wings or silly skins.

The $25 investment makes this game whole, and I would like to see more Castles (this is where you step in) in the community, fighting for epic loot.

Pros:
Replays of all the players who came through your castle... and probably died.
Design your own castle with traps, creatures, and a boss.
Casual gaming style, or spend a whole day trying out user made castles, or work on your castle.
Super fun and 'intoxicated' friendly (just don't leave comments, okay big guy).

Cons:
I wish I had just 25 more 'population' points to put into my castle to get my design down just right.

*If you have an addiction to paying for premium currency, don't be going around sucking **** for **** and seek help. Seriously, because there is no point to rushing your epic items 4 hour counter, it's probably going to be something you don't like anyways. The real loot is into raiding.*

*Update* The Archer needs to be nerfed.  I enjoy playing the other heroes, but the Archer is so OP that it takes the challenge out of the game.

reviewText:
Review as of 5-10-2014, so keep in mind that some things may change later.

So, what is The Mighty Quest for Epic Loot"?

It could be described as a Diablo-style game combined with a bit of dungeon building. Sounds cool
recommended: but let us go into detail on what that means.\n\nBy a Diablo-style game
hoursPlayed: it's a point-and-click hack-and-slash
voteText: similar to Diablo
helpfulPercent: Path of Exile
votesHelpful: etc. So if you're familiar with how those games play
votesTotal: you'll have no problem getting used to this one. If you've never played one of these kind of games
votesFunny: you don't need to worry since the learning curve is rather low
commentsCount: and the game is easy to get into.\n\nYou as a hero venture forth through NPC castles or player castles and try to get to the treasure room
column16: defeating minions and avoiding traps along the way.\n\nThe dungeon building part of the game has you adding room segments to your castle
column17: and filling them with traps and minions  to defend your treasure room from raiding heroes. You can upgrade your treasure storage as well as researching and upgrading minions and traps.\n\nThe game doesn't take itself seriously - for me
column18: this was a nice change of pace from the seriousness that Path of Exile and Diablo has. Some won't like it though
column19: but it's done well.\n\nThere are some negatives with the game
column20: and this mostly comes from the lack of interesting player castles. You'll find many around the level 15/16 range that have traps that are meant to be almost inescapable and result in quick deaths
column21: or very large mobs of minions in a single room with the goal of defeating you with sheer numbers. Ubisoft has done a few things to address the problems created with these designs
column22: however many of these still remain and do leave many people with a feeling of disappointment - not because they failed to get through the castle
column23: but because of the frequency of the design in so many castles.\n\nStill
column25: the game is one you can spend two-three hours in and have some fun."

reviewText:
I played this game for only 33 minutes and had to give up. I didn't get far so I can't go into anything really deep on why I hated this game so quickly. All I can say is that the controls, camera especially, felt insanly clunky. I had a hard time getting anything done and finally just gave up.

The way the camera spins to fixed angles is very annoying. I hate the way the walls vanish, because they didn't vanish in time. I would be walking along, unable to see much in front of me thanks to the bad angles avalable to me and the walls being in my way, then suddenly be under attack.

I personally found the sounds to be rather annoying as well, the voices especially. Though that was a minor thing that just got on my nerves while I was fighting with the camera to try and get a decent view.

reviewText:
Positive

- Gameplay, skills, different tilesets, many options for playstyle, etc... most of the overall design

Negative

- Have to close the game twice manually, launcher stays on your system tray, messing your steam stats among other things.
- Repetitive/Grindy, takes long to level up things or to grind for materials: material's are required to making castle defenses and boosting them to be competitive (boost takes quite a bit of materials and requires many daily if you want to keep it up)
- Compared to earlier versions, a bit too limited defenses.
- Compared to earlier versions, it is now quite a lot more fast-paced and some of the character abilities (and basic attacks) suffer for that. Somehow, even if you aim at a spot, it doesn't always aim there.
- No way to rearrange inventory; lack of inventory space.
- P2W (You can buy monsters or get a pack with pretty much everything)
- Knight lacks so much when compared to rest of the classes
- It's easy to tell which abilities to pick for the endgame on any class
- Certain abilities just cost too much mana for what they do, for example trap disable skills on mage and knight.
- Certain abilities make many challenges (and effectively, tower defense) trivial - for example, runaway's rebel yell and Tank knights lifesteal/shieldings trike build are so broken.
- Certain monsters could be considered P2W - especially manaferatus when paired with small corner rooms and traps so that a mage can't escape from the already insane speed of manaferatu.
- Fire Globuleyes also make many castles unfun - when you get to a small room with buffed or unbuffed fire globuleyes and disable traps for a short while, you haven't got much space to move or dps to kill them because traps will be activated after a while and when that happens, you will be taking high damage and won't have extra mana to keep them disabled. If you try to escape from the room before fire globuleyes are killed once (you have to kill 1 first, then 2 and finally 4 per globuleye), the globuleyes will move to their starting location with full hp. This can be especially frustrating if the defender is smart enough to build 0 defense unit p2w super generators on another room behind such a room so that the traps will stay enabled even if you disable one in such a room... and that's when you'll be avoiding both traps and monsters while not doing much damage.

Still good fun, 8/10

reviewText:
The Mighty Quest For Epic Loot is a great game. You start off by building your castle by completing quests and beating easy AI castles, then, when yours is built, is when the game gets exciting.

You can build different kinds of rooms, sneaky traps, tons of monsters, mana sapping goo castles that fall on your face, barricades, etc. Of course, you have to verify your castle, because if you can't beat your own castle when you know where all the traps and monsters are, who can?

Build your castle, upgrade your core, strengthen your monsters, and go on a mighty quest for epic loot.

Happy looting!

Okay first up this game has been tagged as P2W meaning pay to win for people new to this, but its not.. just ignore that whoever tagged it as that doesnt know what their on about. the premium currancy in the game can get you costume parts, and  new themes for your castle nothing which gives you a massive advantage over others, theres a 4th charecter you can get but all of them are created equal stats and power of the skills its just a different fighting style.

so Ignore the P2W aspect dont let that put you off its a genuinly fun game to go round looting other people's designs and see what they have in stall for you, the only downside i see is that you have to play against your own castle to validate it so others can play against it, and i've been able to create one that is nearly impossible for me to defeat after hours of tinkering and changing things, but also means almost nobody else can get to my treasure room muhahahah >:D

reviewText:
The Mighty Quest For Epic Loot is casual medieval game where you have a castle and a character from one of the 4 classes the game offers; Knight, Archer, Mage, and Runaway which is a sort of Rogue class type. Each class comes with a it's own individual skill tree with skills suited for that class.

The aim of the game is to build up your castle's defences to stop people raiding your gold and loot; which you obtain from raiding other people's castles. It's a vicious cycle of making your character strong with awesome loot that you pillage from other people's castles, to making your castle's defence impenetrable, and then to unlocking new creatures and traps for your castle and new loot for your character.

This game can be incredibly fun to play, but it does have a pay to win feel to it; although even if you pay loads of money into this game, it wont mean anything unless you know how to use what you've bought. For example someone could of bought loads of premium creatures and traps with real money but their castle will still be easy to defeat unless they know how to position them correctly.

So all in all, great game, really fun; but has an element of pay to win in it, and still has a few bugs / issues (like with movement, sometimes your character will just walk into some traps even thought you didn't want it to, but then again all 3rd person games have a few issues with movement).

reviewText: There is something about these kind of games that just hooks me. If you enjoy the mobile games Clash of Clans or the recent one King of Thieves then you will definently enjoy this game. Although it is free to play it feels very balanced and fun. It does have a paid currency though, which is only useful for cosmetic items and buying things you dont have the free currency for, there is also a mine which you can buy with the paid currency to be able to generate that currency for free. There is no waiting for things to build (as far as I can tell) other than when you are crafting items. Overall I would give this game an 7/10. -1 for being f2p (because games could be better if they are not) and a -2 for being integrated with the unholy U-Play.
